paragraphs.name: ad5f
paragraphs.text: We’re always desperately looking for the next big opportunity. The next big business idea, technology to adopt, holiday to plan, house to buy, person to seduce, promotion to acquire.

What do you control? How prepared you are. So stop chasing everything like a happy dog in the park on a summer day. Just keep things simple, work on your skills, character, and become better at a few things every single day.
paragraphs.name: b60e

paragraphs.text: But that idea is broken. Chasing opportunities is a bad strategy. It’s more practical to chase skills, and PREPARE for opportunities.

cc58460a1739.title: Well put, Robert! Thanks for sharing!

paragraphs.text: Well put, Robert! Thanks for sharing!
paragraphs.name: 75b5

paragraphs.text: It isn’t considered an ‘in-thing’ any more to join that group by many excessively brainwashed stupid and unprepared young adults any more.

82a05845bd79.title: Work on your skills and be prepared, act when you’ve rationalised the opportunity well enough to…

paragraphs.text: Work on your skills and be prepared, act when you’ve rationalised the opportunity well enough to know it aligns to your skills and vision for yourself. Got it! Thanks, Darius. 🙃

b79976191c92.title: Good post, Darius, and full of wisdom.

paragraphs.text: Good post, Darius, and full of wisdom. When I was first getting published, I thought I had to learn—and use—everything on social media to get the word out. I wanted to be noticed, reviewed, on the tips of everyone’s tongue. Only I started to forget what my business—my real opportunity is—and that’s writing fiction (humorous fiction). It’s taken 40…
Awesome advice, Darius!
paragraphs.name: ccf4

paragraphs.text: I am still at college and I was in a “interview about some contest” (it was closed door, 1–on-1 though)

c256efaa9fcc.title: Opportunity is when luck meets preparation.

paragraphs.text: Opportunity is when luck meets preparation. Luck smiles at us every day, but if we’re not prepared, we don’t see it; in most cases, we only realize it was an opportunity in hindsight…too late.
paragraphs.name: 30d7

Would love to read more about “opportunity management” and how we can navigate authentically and purpose-driven through live.
